awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  A hand-held device that generates 2D and 3D ultrasound sonograms
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the introduction of a point-of-care ultrasound device that may reduce the cost of data acquisition in research and support scientific advancements in patient care. Currently, over 60% of the world lacks access to ultrasound imaging technology. In addition to prohibitive cost, training also is a barrier. With the implementation of machine learning algorithms, an aspect of guidance and image classification is introduced in the proposed device. This may facilitate the screening of potential complications during pregnancy and provide guidance during breast biopsies, among other applications. To train machine learning algorithms, large datasets need to be generated, but ultrasound data is expensive and slow to collect. In the United States, more than 125 million ultrasound studies are performed yearly at an average cost of $800 each. The main advantages of a broadly accessible ultrasound device are global accessibility to affordable medical diagnostic technology, and a platform for telemedicine software applications. Sonograms may then be shared wirelessly with physicians and healthcare providers, potentially eliminating the need for a physical office visit, which for many is a long, expensive, and complicated journey. This proposed point-of-care ultrasound system will address the needs of global users.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a hand-held, USB (universal serial bus)-powered device that generates 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional ultrasound sonograms and streams images in the same format as webcam video. This video may then be displayed or processed by diagnostic software. The hardware and software are user friendly and applicable for a range of audiences. In addition, artificial intelligence can be used to reduce the training burden for new users. The axial resolution of the proposed portable system is 0.6 mm, lateral resolution is 1.9 mm at 30 mm depth, and central frequency is 4.25 MHz ± 5%. When tested with tissue equivalent phantoms, the device rendered images of sufficient quality to extract value and critical information such as the size of internal structures as well as volumetric information, which may be used to guide clinical decisions. Cart-based ultrasound systems that provide the best-in-market 3-dimensional image quality and processing software can retail for $250,000, which is prohibitive in price for many markets. The proposed point-of-care system may eliminate barriers to diagnostic imaging including price, lack of proficiency in sonogram interpretation, and difficulty reaching medical facilities. The combination of performance, simplicity, and price make this technology broadly accessible and manageable for a range of applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This I-CORPS program involved a customer study to understand the potential commercial landscape for a low-cost user-operatable 3D ultrasound device. We conducted customer interviews to better define our customer and identify who would be paying for this technology (hospitals vs home users vs doctors). During this COVID-19 era we understand that patients and doctors would both benefit from at-home monitoring approaches to minimize hospital visits.  For procedures such as in vitro fertilization, multiple ultrasound scans are required on a weekly basis to monitor procedures. An at-home solution may be beneficial and time saving for prospective mothers who would be able to wirelessly send their results to their medical practitioner. We also see an opportunity to utilize our contrast imaging in software. This is valuable in assisting during needle guidance procedures via interventional image guidance. Ultrasound-guided procedures are common and in recent years, there has been an increase in biopsy procedures performed under ultrasound guidance. CT guidance was once the standard imaging modality for guiding biopsies of retroperitoneal masses, musculoskeletal masses, pleural-based masses, and deep masses in the liver, are now being successfully performed using ultrasound guidance. We hypothesized that our system can meet the standard needed to image guidance and be relied-upon for a range of applications including breast cancer needle guidance, tracheostomy, catheter insertion in the groin for cardiovascular stenting, or even IV injection procedures.

We spoke with over 30 OBGYNs during the course of interviews to validate this. Due to COVID times, some patients have opted to remain at home and remote monitoring has been on the rise. Or so we thought. From speaking with Dr. Hesham from The Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, we learned that doctors are uncomfortable with performing imaging outside of the hospital and preferred controlled settings where medical intervention was possible. We have continued customer discovery in the geriatrics space and felt more confused than ever.  

From continued conversations regarding remote patient management and speaking with Dr. Pete Gilatto from Mount Sinai, we learned that there may be an opportunity to address needs in geriatric care, and by interviewing traveling geriatricians, we heard that ultrasound is useful during at-home evaluation of the bladder because not assessing could lead to urinary tract infections, and increased hospitalizations. Overall, there are two ways that such services are provided (one through hospital-affiliated visiting physician groups and another through private visiting physician companies.

At this point, not only have we defied a user, but we also defined a clinical application, buyer, and potential competitors! This is a lot of learning and we now see why the teaching team was pushing us to focus. Our team has been is excited to continue customer discovery and learn about how our minimum viable product can address the needs of our customers including surpassing performance limitations that our competitors have and increasing the accuracy of bladder assessment.

Fig. 1 in the final report summarizes the lessons learned and shows our first insights into the effects of underutilizing POCUS for at-home elderly patient monitoring. Fluid retention (from improper filling or emptying of the organ) is an issue that can land patients in the hospital. This is a fairly simple scan to perform. While we are targeting small and rural US towns, we still received feedback from larger metropolitan hospitals regarding the programs, equipment, and training that would be needed for successful screening.
